Do you mean as an applet? We've never considered that deployment 
scenario, there could be issues. In particular, we're always assuming 
lots of IO to local disk paths.

All the bundled JARs are necessary, though if you were skipping the use 
of certain extractor options (like Flash, Office DOCs, etc.) a few could 
be dropped.

Each library would have to be evaluated individually as to whether a 
later version would be an acceptable substitute. I've usually had good 
luck rolling forward to new versions of Apache libraries, but you never 
know until you try. (Where it is harmless, we'd be happy to update the 
official builds on request/report-of-no-problems, but usually only do so 
when there is a need for a fix or new functionality in the current 
versions.)

- Gordon @ IA

On 2/9/11 5:14 AM, psiinon wrote:
> Hi folks,
>
> I'm looking for a crawler that I can embed in a client side Java app (the OWASP Zed Attack Proxy).
> Heritrix looks good, but I'm worried about the number of jars in the lib directory, and the fact that many of them are out of date.
> For example, we already use commons-lang 1.4, codex 1.4 and logging 1.1.1.
> I dont want to revert these (or any other jars) to older versions.
> Can anyone tell me what the minimum set of jars I can add to my app in order to use Heritrix inline? And if I'm likely to hit problems if I use later versions of any of them?
>
> Many thanks,
